body.name: Aliens: Bishop: A Novel
body.description: A direct sequel to Aliens and Alien 3—Weyland-Yutani, the Colonial Marines, and Bishop’s creator all pursue the android for the deadly Xenomorph data contained in his brain. Written by T. R. Napper, author of the acclaimed 36 Streets, whose explosive work explores the artificial intelligence and what it is to be human.Massively damaged in Aliens and Alien 3, the synthetic Bishop asked to be shut down forever. His creator, Michael Bishop, has other plans. He seeks the Xenomorph knowledge stored in the android’s mind and brings Bishop back to life—but for what reason? No longer an employee of the Weyland-Yutani Corporation, Michael tells his creation that he seeks to advance medical research for the benefit of humanity. Yet where does he get the resources needed to advance his work. With whom do his new allegiances lie?Bishop is pursued by Colonial Marines Captain Marcel Apone, commander of the Il Conde and younger brother of Master Sergeant Alexander Apone, one of the casualties of the doomed mission to LV-426. Also on his trail are the “Dog Catchers,” commandos employed by Weyland-Yutani.Who else might benefit from Bishop’s intimate knowledge of the deadliest creatures in the galaxy? Read more

productInformation.name: Narrator

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Okay. I just finished reading Bishop. It actually surprised me. While the beginning had me worried that it was being tailored to "modern audiences", once I finished the story I was very surprised that it was a very enjoyable read. There are several callbacks to the movie Aliens, including Alien 3 as well. And funnily enough, there's one quote in the book from a certain individual that is almost a direct quote from the movie Apocalypse Now. So go figure. But what I did like was that while the story was not as cliched that some of the other ones had been previous, this one showed some pretty good character development and a lot of nuance. And there's even a surprise character in it that I was not expecting that was a fun addition and with his character there were some very, very subtle callbacks to one of the two movies I mentioned earlier. It actually made me chuckle out loud. And the character of Bishop was written very well with a lot of care, which was very appreciated. So definitely check this book out, it is not what I expected and I was thoroughly surprised by it. And the ending does leave open quite a few possibilities. Some of which are pretty terrifying for that universe.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Evolution of Bishop
reviews.reviewText: The concept of this book had me hooked when I read the blurb. Bishop was one of my favorite characters in Aliens and I wanted to see what happened to him after Alien 3. This story is told from a variety of viewpoints, in audiobook, they are all voiced by different narrators. I think it unfolds better on audio. Sgt Apone's brother mounts an unauthorized mission to rescue Bishop's remains. His turns out not to be the only one. Others are interested in what his brain knows, including Bishop's creator Michael Bishop. Weyland Utani is not the only organization looking to weaponize the Xenomorphs, several other groups as well. We are introduced to a Chinese effort. The story jumps back and forth between viewpoints instead of a straight narration. The first part drags a bit, but my favorites were the Bishop episodes. They really dealt with the creator's motives and Bishop's growing conscience. Needless to say, things happen, it all goes south and who is left standing. Once it gets going, its pretty good.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A great end to the saga! Or is it the end?
reviews.reviewText: Been watching the movies and reading the books since I was in the single digit midget category. ( I was 8 when I first snuck a peek at Aliens). Its become an obsession and I wasn't thrilled about the way the original saga ended, though the effects were top notch. I like how this went and hope like he'll the author continues.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2023
reviews.reviewText: As a fan of the movies growing up I went into this kinda iffy but was I drew in and kept in this really has the feel of all those stories!!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2023
reviews.reviewText: If you're a fan of the ALIEN series and want to see an actual followup to the third film, this book is for you. I hope Napper gets a crack at more ALIEN books soon.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I have seen all the aliens movies, and this book Was hard to put down and very entertaining.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I really enjoyed reading this book. It really expands on the mythos of the Alien Universe and adds an even more sinister side to the big companies of the series.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I love the book, but it came ripped on the cover, all my books were free floating in the box.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 16, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This is easily one of the best Alien Novels in recent years, this one actually felt like it was in the same universe as the original movies, the descriptions put me right back watching those movies for the first time.The action flows well with some interesting directions along the way, characters are given just enough paper time and arcs to make you not want them to die, it also not take away from the story (which would be my only gripe about the book and Apones reasoning for rescuing Bishop and continuously loosing so many lives), but once you roll with it, then the book grabs you and pulls you in.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 12, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: Good but could have been Great
reviews.reviewText: I have been a long-term fan of the Alien universe, and the synthetics of this universe have always been of great interest. I’m just going to say it, Ash in the OG Alien was one of my favourites characters. So a novel based on Bishop one of the franchises most famous synthetics was a lure I couldn’t resist, I was also keen to read this as it mentioned Bishops creator going rogue. In all honesty Michael Bishop proved to be one of the most interesting aspects of the novel, his drives, motivations and megalomania where quite interesting. Maybe its just me but I feel every Alien novel just rehashes the same personalities for the colonial marines, you know the types, orphan with a dark past, macho muscle ape etc etc. I find it a little tedious now. This book had potential to deviate from some of the dross Alien novels we have received before but never quite realises its full potential. In summary some enjoyable parts but felt quite short and rushed.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 15, 2023
reviews.reviewText: This is the best alien book I have read for a long time Theirs no political agendas in this book I don't want to read a authors preferences I want a good story and this book excels I have read every titan book and this is one of the best If you like alien read this book
